articles.title: Observations
articles.summary: This article from the SJAA announces several upcoming events and initiatives for its members, including general meetings with notable speakers like a Solar Physics expert and a Saturn ring expert. It details a reduced-rate subscription offer for Astronomy Magazine, a new telescope-making class, and a dedicated 'beginner's night' for new telescope owners. Additionally, it highlights external astronomical resources such as a solar activity hotline and a comet news service.

articles.title: The Astronomical Society of the Pacific
articles.summary: The Astronomical Society of the Pacific is offering a free directory of national amateur astronomical associations. The article also discusses the growing scientific acceptance of the idea of asteroid satellites, highlighting observations by SJAA members of secondary occultations. Additionally, several SJAA members are recognized for their recent contributions to various astronomy-related magazines and publications.

articles.title: The American Institute of Aeronautics and Astronautics
articles.summary: The American Institute of Aeronautics and Astronautics (AIAA) is sponsoring a competition offering two $5,000 prizes to undergraduate student teams for proposals to secure Space Shuttle payload space from NASA. Additionally, the article includes announcements for a Red Cross blood drive, a reminder about sharing public star party sites with other amateur astronomers, and a call for more submissions for the club's bulletin.

articles.title: New Addresses
articles.summary: This document, titled "New Addresses," provides updated contact details for several individuals, including their residential addresses and phone numbers. It also lists names and contact numbers for key organizational roles such as president, vice-president, and editor.

articles.title: COMET COMMENTS
articles.summary: This article provides an update on comet observations as of late 1980. It notes two periodic comets departing, one remaining, and a new discovery. Notably, Comet Helin-Dunbar (1980p) was determined to be a ghost image, while Comet Meier (1980q) was a new discovery observed in November 1980, with details on its brightness and trajectory.

articles.title: Comet Meier (1980q)
articles.summary: This document provides astrometric data for Comet Meier (1980q), detailing its Right Ascension, Declination, and observed magnitude for several dates in November. It notes the comet's southwest trajectory and advises observers to look for it in late November after the full moon before it enters twilight.

articles.title: And our three periodic comets....
articles.summary: This article provides an observational guide for three periodic comets: Stephen-Oterma (1980g), Tuttle (1980h), and Encke. It details their ephemerides, including Right Ascension, Declination, and estimated magnitudes for observations from November 1980 to January 1981. Each comet's path and visibility are briefly described, supplemented by personal observing notes from mid-November.

articles.title: Comets in Your Eyes: Reporting a comet discovery.
articles.summary: This article provides a step-by-step guide for amateur astronomers on how to report a potential comet discovery. It details initial checks to confirm a fuzzy object is indeed a comet, the specific information required, and the preferred method of reporting via telegram to the Smithsonian Astrophysical Observatory's Central Bureau for Astronomical Telegrams. The document also includes contact information for follow-up and additional resources.

articles.title: NOVEMBER 8 STAR PARTY AT FREMONT PEAK
articles.summary: The November 8 star party at Fremont Peak experienced low attendance from SJAA members, despite good sky conditions and bearable temperatures. The author focused on observing various celestial objects with a new Celestron 14, sharing views of globular clusters and nebulae with other attendees. The event featured diverse telescopes, some minor equipment issues, and concluded with a practical tip for preserving night vision when departing.

articles.title: Behind the Scenes at Voyager-Saturn
articles.summary: This article provides a humorous, behind-the-scenes look at the Press Room during the Voyager-Saturn encounter at JPL. It recounts amusing anecdotes involving Carl Sagan, a national TV reporter's unusual ideas for supporting the space program, and a journalist's notable lack of scientific knowledge. The piece also includes a satirical, fictional description of an image from Titan.
